Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Novel Tracer Approach to Estimate the Atmospheric Input of Trace Elements into the Global Ocean
Award.AbstractNarration:
The atmospheric input of numerous chemical species into the global ocean equals or exceeds that from river sources and thus constitutes an important budgetary component for these elements. In addition, the atmospheric input of trace elements plays a key role in ocean biogeochemical processes. Assessment of this input is difficult however because measurements of deposition rates to the ocean are rare and susceptible to problems of temporal and spatial variability. Given the dearth of direct measurements, the ocean community must rely on atmospheric transport and deposition models which themselves are poorly constrained as to rainfall amounts and aerosol removal parameterization. Thus indirect methods, such as the use of natural radionuclides delivered to the ocean from the atmosphere are often used to estimate atmospheric inputs.

In a novel application developed in this project, researchers at the University of Miami and Florida State University will use measurements of 7Be in the surface waters and in the lower atmosphere, coupled with trace element measurements in aerosols and rain, to provide estimates of the atmospheric input of relevant trace elements into the subtropical North Atlantic. 7Be is a cosmic ray produced radioisotope that becomes associated with particles in the troposphere and subsequently deposited to the surface ocean. Because of its relatively short half-life (53.3 days) it is reasonable to equate the inventory of 7Be decay in the upper ocean to the flux of 7Be from the atmosphere due to wet plus dry deposition. This provides a key linkage between the atmospheric concentration of chemical species and their deposition to the ocean. Such species include many of interest to the GEOTRACES program such as Al, Mn, Fe, Cu, Zn, and Cd. The atmospheric flux of these important trace elements (TEs) can then be estimated from multiplying the 7Be atmospheric flux (determined by its ocean inventory) by the TE/7Be ratios in aerosols and wet deposition.

Broader Impacts: This research will directly addresse one of the critical objectives in the International GEOTRACES Science Plan: "Develop and refine chemical tracers in the surface ocean for quantification of atmospheric deposition". The ability to provide estimates of the atmospheric input of relevant trace elements to the ocean will contribute widely to the field of chemical oceanography and elsewhere, including understanding anthropogenic impacts on the oceans and the role atmospheric input of TEs plays in ocean ecology. The results of this project will benefit other international initiatives such as the SOLAS program, and data generated in this work will be available to allow ground-truthing of models of aerosol deposition and atmospheric input. Education and training of graduate students are essential components of this research. The PIs regularly teach undergraduate and graduate classes and incorporate the results of their fieldwork into lecture materials to motivate the next generation of Earth scientists. Undergraduate FSU chemistry and/or biology majors (males, females, minorities) will be involved in the research via annual requests for REU supplements. As they evolve, results will be presented at national/international scientific meetings, and published in peer-reviewed journals. The data will be submitted in a timely manner according to the requirements of NSF/OCE.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Phytoplankton photosynthesis in the oceans accounts for about 50% of the total photosynthesis on the Earth. Some of the organic matter produced by phytoplankton from carbon dioxide (CO2) in the oceans sinks into the deep ocean where it stays for hundreds of years. This flux is about equal to the amount of CO2 released to the atmosphere every year from fossil fuel burning and land-use changes like deforestation. Since phytoplankton photosynthesis removes so much CO2 from the upper ocean, it is important to understand as much as possible about how that process works. Climate science tells us that rising CO2 levels in the atmosphere should cause climate change (global warming), and our models for climate change therefore rely on understanding how quickly phytoplankton can turn CO2 into organic matter. This will improve the accuracy of our future climate change predictions.

 

In order to convert CO2 into organic matter during photosynthesis, phytoplankton in the oceans require a suite of essential trace elements including manganese, iron, cobalt, and zinc for proper biological function. Just as any garden needs the right balance of nutrients and trace elements, it has been estimated that phytoplankton photosynthesis is limited by the supply of iron in about 40% of the world’s oceans. In the open ocean far from river input these essential trace elements are supplied in large part from deposition of atmospheric dust (coming from arid desert regions and urban areas). Historically, it has been hard to accurately measure the deposition of aerosols carrying these essential trace elements, so we conducted this study to find a better way. This project “Collaborative research: A novel tracer approach to estimate the atmospheric input of trace elements into the global ocean” was designed to test whether we could use the natural flux of radioactive beryllium (Be-7) from the atmosphere to the oceans to help us measure the deposition of other important trace elements. Berylium-7 is a cosmogenic radionuclide; it is produced in the atmospheric by cosmic ray collisions with nitrogen gas and decays to Li-7 with a 53 day half-life. The basis for the project is that the supply of Be-7 atoms from atmospheric deposition to the upper ocean should be balanced by its radioactive decay. So, by collecting the Be-7 in the upper ocean and summing up all of its decay, we can calculate its atmospheric flux rate to the ocean. Then, by measuring the ratios of trace elements to Be-7 in aerosols and multiplying those ratios by the flux rate of Be-7, we can calculate the flux rate for any other trace element. Our results show that this idea (the “Be-7 method”) works!

 

To test the method, we collected aerosol and rainfall samples at the Bermuda Institute of Ocean Sciences field station to measure the ratios of trace elements to Be-7, and we also measured the inventory of Be-7 decay in the waters surrounding the island. We compared the atmospheric aerosol fluxes of trace elements that we calculates using the Be-7 method to the actual fluxes we measured from rainfall as well as fluxes we calculates using older methods, and found that the Be-7 method yields reliable results. By collecting similar data on research expeditions from anywhere in the oceans, we can now calculate the atmospheric deposition flux of biologically essential trace elements to the upper ocean. This allows us to understand how much CO2 will be converted to organic matter, and will help make our climate change predictions more reliable.

 

Our results were recently published in a journal article:

Kadko D., W. M. Landing, and R. U. Shelley. A novel tracer technique to quantify the atmospheric flux of trace elements to remote ocean regions. Journ. Geophy. Res. Oceans, 119...
